message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden and severe pain, vomiting, absence of the cremasteric reflex, and a transverse lie of the left testis suggest testicular torsion. Epididymitis would be associated with dysuria and frequency, mumps orchitis would have a prodromal viral illness, and germ cell tumor would be asymptomatic or present with a painless mass. Ultrasonographic examination may confirm the diagnosis of testicular torsion. Emergency surgery is needed to detorse the testis and if necessary, surgical fixation of the testis to prevent future occurrences.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden and severe pain, absence of dysuria or frequency, and elevated/swollen testis with a transverse lie suggest that the most likely diagnosis is testicular torsion. Epididymitis presents with gradual onset of pain and tenderness, while mumps orchitis presents with unilateral or bilateral testicular swelling and pain after 4–7 days of fever, headache, myalgia, and malaise. Germ cell tumor would not present with sudden onset of pain. Ultrasonographic examination would confirm the diagnosis and assess for testicular blood flow.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe pain, vomiting, and absence of the cremasteric reflex are all highly suggestive of testicular torsion. All other options do not present with sudden onset of severe pain and vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe pain, vomiting, and absent cremasteric reflex, suggests the most likely diagnosis is testicular torsion. Epididymitis and Mumps orchitis tend to be less sudden and present with less severe symptoms. Germ cell tumor is less likely in an 11-year-old boy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe pain with vomiting suggests testicular torsion, especially with the absence of the cremasteric reflex and the transverse lie of the left testis. Epididymitis would have dysuria and frequency, and germ cell tumors and mumps orchitis would not have sudden onset with severe pain. Ultrasonographic examination can confirm the diagnosis. Emergency surgery is necessary to salvage the testis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe pain in the left scrotum, vomiting, and absence of the cremasteric reflex are all suggestive of testicular torsion. The other options are less likely, as they usually do not present with sudden onset and vomiting. Ultrasonographic examination can confirm the diagnosis. Immediate surgical intervention is needed for testicular torsion to prevent testicular infarction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe pain in the left scrotum with vomiting and the absence of dysuria or frequency suggests a testicular torsion. The swelling, tenderness, and absence of cremasteric reflex further support this diagnosis. Ultrasonographic examination can confirm the diagnosis. Epididymitis and mumps orchitis usually have a slower onset and are associated with other symptoms such as dysuria and fever. Germ cell tumors typically present with a painless scrotal mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden and severe pain in the left scrotum with no history of trauma, along with swelling, erythema, tenderness, and absent cremasteric reflex all point towards testicular torsion as the most likely diagnosis. Ultrasonographic examination can confirm the diagnosis. Epididymitis and mumps orchitis usually present with a gradual onset of pain and are less likely given the sudden onset of symptoms. Germ cell tumors rarely present in children and are usually painless.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden and severe pain, absence of trauma and dysuria, and the physical exam findings of swollen and tender scrotum with a transverse lie of the left testis and absent cremasteric reflex suggest testicular torsion, which requires immediate surgical intervention to avoid testicular loss. The other options do not typically present with such sudden and severe symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe pain, vomiting, absence of dysuria or frequency, and the physical examination findings suggest testicular torsion as the most likely diagnosis. Epididymitis is usually gradual in onset, accompanied by dysuria and/or frequency, and the cremasteric reflex is usually present. Germ cell tumors are usually painless and do not have sudden onset. Mumps orchitis can cause testicular pain and swelling but usually occurs after an acute mumps infection and is rarely associated with torsion.
